ALEXANDER M'KAY (policeman, M 265.) On Tuesday evening, at a quarter before five, I was passing Mr. Jones' shop, and saw two rolls for gutta percha—about six o'clock I saw the prisoner at he shop-window, and after
wards met a man, not the prisoner, with a roll similar to what I had seen—I though the prisoner belonged to the shop, and let him pass me—I them followed him, and next saw he gutta percha on his shoulder—I stopped him and asked what he was going to do with it—he said he was going to his master's—I asked who his master was—he dropped it, and said a man promised him a pint of beer to carry it.

Prisoner. Q. Why did not you stop the other man? A. I thought he belonged to the shop—another man was taken up three weeks after—I did not take him, as I had a doubt—the other man had it in his hand, not on his shoulder—the second man who was taken up was taken for the one who

escaped—I never had a doubt of you—I never let go of you—I did lose sight of the second man momentarily—you were twenty-five yards down the court, looking in at the window—the shop is the whole length of the court.
Prisoner's Defence. A man asked me to carry it, and said he would give me a drop of beer; if I had known it was stolen I should not have taken it.

955.
NAOMI FROST
, sealing 3lbs. weight of bacon, value 2s.; the goods of
Thomas Mason.

RICHARD GOLDING (policeman, V 31.) On 17th Feb., about twelve o'clock in the day, I met the prisoner at Merton Rush, going from Wimbledon to
wards her home—I stopped her, and asked if she had anything belonging to any one else in her basket—she said "No"—I said I must see—she said she had a piece of bacon—I found she had two pieces, and said, "I must take you to the station"—she said she hoped I would not take her to Mr. Mason's—I took her to the station, and then took the bacon to Mr. Mason's, and saw it fitted to some bacon, it corresponded.

THOMAS CHILTOM. I am shopman to Thomas Mason, of Wimbledon. On 17th Feb. the prisoner came and bought some tea, soap, and salt, but no bacon—I served her—there was some bacon on the next counter, two yards from her—I went to the back of the shop for the salt—she paid me and went away—Golding afterwards brought me some bacon—I then missed a piece—this is the piece which remained (produced)—it fits exactly—I am quite sure it had been in the shop—I am not certain of the other piece.
JURY. Q. Can you swear that one piece was in the shop when the prisoner was there? A. No.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up in a hedge and put it into my bundle; I said to the policeman, "Take me back to Mr. Mason's, where I have been; i have not stolen it."

RICHARD GOLDING
re-examined. I am sure she did not say so—I saw her coming out of Mr. Mason's that morning, and should have stopped her them, but a gentleman stopped me.

956.
JOHN HENRY ALLEN
, stealing 1 shawl, 2 aprons, and 1 frock, value 11s.; the goods of
George Allen; and
ELIZA CHALLANDER
, feloniously receiving the same; to which

ALLEN pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 14.—
Confined One Month.

MARY ANN ALLEN. I am the wife of George Allen, of Suffolk-street, Southwark—the prisoner is my son—this shawl, frock, and two aprons, are mine (produced)—my boy was charged with stealing them—he said he had taken them.—(MR. METCALFE objected to any confession of Allen's, implica
ting Challander, being given; Allen not being on his trial [see Rex v. Turner, 1st Moody's Crown Cases, page 347.]—Allen's confession was not received.)—in consequence of what he said to me, I went with Wise to Chal
lander's house—he asked her if she had bought a shawl—she denied it—she had the apron on—Wise searched, and found some pawnbroker's tickets—he said, "Here is a ticket for a shawl"—she said that was not the shawl; that was her own—we went to the pawnbroker's, and found my shawl.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not she say the ticket was for her daughter's shawl? A. She may; I did not hear what she said to the policeman—It is not a large room—I was on the other side to the policeman—I said, "That is my apron"—she said, "If it is yours take it."

JOHN WISE (policeman, M 84.) I took Allen, and then went with his father and mother to Challander's—I asked if she recollected buying some shawls, a child's frock, and some apron of a boy—she said she brought a frock of a boy for 4d.—I asked of she had brought any shawls—she said, "No"—I asked if she would allow me to search—she said, "Yes"—I searched, and in a drawer under the bedstead I found a child's frock—I asked where the apron were—she handed over one, which Mrs. Allen did not identify; but she did the one she wore—I saw Wild find a ticket for the shawl; it was shown to the prisoner—she said it was her daughter's shawl.

GEORGE WILD (policeman.) I am at the house, and after the prisoner had said that was all the. duplicates she had, I found three in an image on the shelf—I said, "Here is something relating to a shawl"—she said, "That is my daughter's—I went with Mr. and Mrs. Allen to Mr. Bennett, a pawn
broker's, in St. George's-circus, produced the ticket, and this shawl was pro
duced—as I was going out at the door, I said, "I shall go and see your daughter"—the prisoner said, "Don't trouble yourself, for that is the shawl I brought of the boy Allen; I gave him 1s. for it."

Cross-examined. Q. Have you said that before? A. I do not know that I have—the other witness were outside the door then—she went before the Magistrate to indentify the boy, and then said the gave 15d. for it—she was then taken in charge—I did not take ker at the time, as I had a sum
mons for her as a witness—Mr. Cottingham did not reprimand me—the clerk said I ought to have taken her into custody.

CATHERINE BARNETT. I live at 21, Fleet-street. On Saturday morning, two days before this charge, Allen came and offered me this shawl for 18d., and said his mother wanted to sell it—I said, "I can only give him 1s."—he said, "My mother will not take less than 18d."—he took it to another house in the street—he said his mother was in great distress.
(Challander received a good character)

957.
THOMAS WILLIAMS
, stealing 2 pairs of trowsers, value 14s., the goods of
James Baster; and
WILLIAM WHITING
, feloniously re
ceiving the same; both having been before convicted.

JANE BASTER. I am of James Baster, a clothier and outfitter. On 10th Feb., about seven o'clock in the evening, I was in my parlour, heard a noise, looked through the partition, and saw man, with his head above the counter, on his hands and knees—I went in—he got away—I missed two pairs of trowsers from the counter near the door, which I had seen safe five minutes before—they are my husband's goods—I saw the man's face—to the best of my knowledge it was Williams—he had on a cap, and a dark coat—I saw him next at Greenwich police-court—the things have not been found.

WILLIAM NOAKES (policeman, M. 104.) On 10th Feb., about seven o'clock, I received information, and saw whiting and two man at the entrance of the Thames Tunnel—I passed on a hundred and fifty yards, and met Williams coming towards the Tunnel from Deptford, carrying a bundle—I stopped him, and said I was a constable, and asked what he had in the bundle—he

said, "Slop work"—I asked what it was—he said, "Two pairs of trowsers"—I said, "What sort?"—he said, "A pair of cloth, and a pair of cord ones"—I saw part of the cord trowsers, and part of some blue cloth ones, and did not undo the bundle—I asked him where he brought them from—he said from his grandmother, at Greenwich, and he was going to his aunt, in the Commercial-road—I said he must go with me to the station—he went quietly till we came to where the other three were, and then he said he should go no further—I said he must—he looked towards the three men, said, "Here," threw the bundle down, and attempted to get away—Whiting picked it up—Williams said, "Step it"—I told Whiting to put it down, two or three times, and said it was stolen—he was close to me—Williams made another attempt to get away, and said to Whiting, "Go on"—after the scuffle was over, I found Whiting and the other two were gone—I took Williams to the station—he gave his address, 7, Cornwall-street—I went, and found he did not live there—on Friday night Whiting was brought by Potter—I knew him directly, and said, "That is the man that went off with the trowsers over the water"—he said he had not been over the water for some mcnths—I am sure he is the man.
Whiting. Q. Could you swear to the other men? A. I have seen one since, hanging about here.

WILLIAM CHARLES POTTER (policeman, K 212.) I took Whiting in Angel-gardens, on 18th Feb.—I said I wanted him on suspicion of being with Browncy over the water, and stealing two pairs of trowsers—he said, "so help me God I was not there"—I had known him eighteen months, and Williams three or four years, and have seen them together three or four times since Christmas.
Whiting. Q. Did not you stop me the night before you took me, and ask if I had heard about Browncy? A. No; I did see you.
JAMES BASTER. I am the prosecutor—I was away when the trowsers were lost—as I was coming home, I saw Whiting at the Surrey entrance of the Thames Tunnel, about half a mile from my shop.
Williams' Defence. I know nothing of it; I have known Whiting a long while; he is not the man.
Whiting's Defence. I was not on that side of the water that day; I had not seen Browncy for days before.
JAMES PYE (policeman, K111.) I produce certificates of the prisoner conviction—(read—Convicted Sept., 1847,and confined three months)—I was present at the trial—they are the persons.

WILLIAMS—
GUILTY. Aged 21.

WHITING—
GUILTY. Aged 26.

958.
THOMAS BEST and
HENRY JOSLING
, stealing I butter
dish, value 5s., the goods of
Maurice James Harris; both having been before convicted; to which

JOSLING pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 15.—
Confined Six Months.

ELIZABETH HARRIS. I am the wife of Maurice James Harris, of the Water
loo-road—he keeps an oyster-shop. On Monday evening, 31st Jan., between ten and eleven o'clock, I missed a plated dish from the shop window, which I had seen safe about ten—there was a broken pane in the window, which had a board against it—a person could get the dish by putting his band through there.

JAMES BEDLIN (policeman, L 133.) On Monday, 31st Jan., about a quarter to eleven o'clock in the evening, I was on duty in the Waterloo-road, and saw the two prisoners together, walking backwards and forwards, in front of the shop—I saw Best put his hand through the broken square, take out some
thing which glittered, and pass it to Josling—they then ran away—I ran after them, and took Josling—I am quite sure Best is the other—I had seen them the night before, and took notice of them—I took Best on the 10th Feb., told him what for, and he said he knew nothing at all of it.
Best's Defence. My father can prove I was a-bed at the time; Joaling knows I am innocent.
DAVID PHILLIPS (policeman, B 54.) I produce a certificate—(read—Thomas Best, convicted Feb., 1847, and confined six months)—I was present—he is the person.

BEST—
GUILTY. Aged 16.—
Confined Twelve Months.

959.
JOSEPH WESTLEY
, stealing 2 cans, 7 quarts of japan, and 4 quarts of turpentine, value 1l. 18s.; the goods of the
South Eastern Railway Company.

JOHN BRIGHTMAN. I am a lamplighter, in the employ of the South Me
tropolitan Gas-works Company, Kent-road—I have lived in that neighbour
hood nine years. On 17th Jan., between five and six o'clock in the evening, I was in Upper Grange-road, near the yard of the Bricklayers' Arms station—I saw the prisoner at the corner of Willow-walk, lurking about—I kept my eye on him some time—I believe his hand were in his pockets—it was a wet, cold night—he went down Willow-walk, and then to a recess, which leads to the company's fence—he went to the fence—I watched him on the opposite side of the way—there is a little hillock at the bottom of the recess, and when a man was on that, the fence would be about breast high—I saw something at the top of the fence—I withdrew, and stood about fifty yards off, and saw the prisoner come out of the recess with a can in each hand—he went down Willow-walk to the Grange-road—I followed him about a quarter of a mile, met a policeman, told him, and he said to the prisoner, "What have you got here?"—he said, "I brought it from home"—I said, "That is not true"—he said, "You are a false man"—the policeman said, "Where are you going to take it?"—he said, "Home," and said, "Come with me, and I will make it all right"—I policeman took him—I took him back to where be brought the property from—he denied that he had been there—on the way to the station he said he came from Clerkenwell, and was going to take it to a man at Camberwell—he was asked again at the station where he was going to take it—he said to a man named Oldham, at the Swan, in Old Kent-road—he said he had got about two quarts of turps—the policeman said, "Could you swear to these cans if I were to take them from you, and produce them to-morrow? are there any marks on them?"—he said, "None whatever."

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. How long have you been a lighter to the company? A. Twelve months—I am a tailor by trade—I had never seen the prisoner till that evening, that I remember—I had done my work about five o'clock in Russell-street—I had about twenty minutes' walk to my own home—I was going as quickly as possible—I passed the prisoner rather quickly—he was not walking, but lurking about—I returned again, seeing he

moved from the position he was in, and watched every one that passed—I never lost sight of him till he went towards the fence, and then only for four or five minutes—no one else was in the recess—he went in without this pro
perty and returned with it.

JOHN WEATHERHEAD. I am station-master at the Bricklayers' Arms station of the South Eastern Railway—between 300 and 400 person are employed there—some of them have access to the stores—japan and turpentine are kept there in large quantities—one of these cans contains japan, and the other turpentine—the company had property of this sort in their store in such cans—I am positive of this japan-can—here is writing on a former label which has been partly torn off this other can—I would not swear positively to it, but it corresponds in all respects with those we have; and so does the japan and turpentine—I have brought some from the station—this is worth about 2l. 4s. with the cans—I never saw the prisoner till he was in custody—people could get to the fence by going across a field.
Cross-examined. Q. You do not know anything of the qualities of japan or turps? A. I do, by seeing the men use it constantly—I do not think there are 100 two-gallon cans similar to these.

JAMES BISSICKS. I am in the employ of Charles Turner, a varnish-maker—he supplies japan and turps to the South Eastern Railway Company—I have tested this japan—it corresponds in all respects with the japan supplied to the company by Mr. Turner—the part of a label on one can has my writing on it—I believe both these cans are part of the stores supplied to the company—both bear a "T," the initial of Mr. Turner's name.
Cross-examined. Q. When you gave the can with that writing on, you are not aware? A. No—part of it is broken off—whether that japan was all used I cannot tell.

PHILIP FROWED. I am inspector of the M division of police. I knew Thomas Marshall, the policeman in this case—he died since last Sessions—this is his writing to this deposition—(read—"Thomas Marshall, policeman, M 254, says):—On Monday last, 17th instant, about twenty minutes to six o'clock, I saw the prisoner carrying the two cans produced; Brightman gave me information; I stopped the prisoner, and asked what he had there; he said, 'Some turps;' I asked where he was going; he said, 'Home;' I asked him where; he said, 'Come with me and you shall see;' I asked him where he had been, and where he had brought it from; he said from home, and he was going to take it back again; Brightman said he would show where the prisoner had brought it from, and we all went together to the Williow-walk; Brightman pointed out the passage from which he had seen him bring the cans; the prisoner said he had been there to case himself; I asked how he came to be there; he said he had been to Camberwell, and afterwards to the Swan in the Old Kent-road; both of those places are out of the line of road; the prisoner tole me the cans contained about two quarts of turps; I found one contained about seven quarts of turps, and the other two quarts of japan.")

GUILTY. Aged 45.—
Confined Four Months.

960.
JAMES HENRY PHILLIPS
, embezzling the sums of 9s. 6d., 12s. 6d., and 1l. 19s. 3d., which he had received on account of
William Thomas Cupit and others, his masters.
MR. BODKIN. offered no evidence.
(There were two other charges against the prisoner, on which no evidence was offered.)

961.
WILLIAM ROBERTS
, stealing 1 pewter pot, value 1s., the goods of
John Dooley.
JOHN DOOLEY. I am a publican, at 61, Old Bailey. I missed this pewter pot about 11th Jan. (produced)—I believe I had seen it safe that day.

GEORGE WILD (policeman, M 94.) I received information, and went to a house in Hope-place, Borough-road—the prisoner lodged at the top of the house—I saw the landlord, and waited till the prisoner came home at past eleven o'clock at night; and when he opened his room door I walked in after him—he tried to prevent me, but I got in and found two pots—I took him in charge, and on the following morning I found this pot there is a hamper, under a lot of things—he said some one had put it into his room, or I had put it there myself.

Prisoner. Q. What time were you there? A. I had information three days before I went to the house—when you got in, you said, "Good God, I wish I was out of the place"—I said, "I am a constable"—you said, "I thought it was my landlord"—you showed me the room—you did not tell my where the pot was to go.
MARY ANN LEECH. I saw the prisoner bend up pots between two pieces of rag on the night before he was taken.

Prisoner's Defence. The landlord look the house where I reside, and next day he gave me notice to quit; it did not suit me to move, and he had annoyed me in every way; he took away some furniture of mine and gave me no account of it, and then I was charged with pot-stealing; I was at the Auction
mart, and never went home till past eleven o'clock; I could not have taken this pot.

GUILTY. Aged 42.—
Confined Nine Months.

962.
HENRY TURNER
, unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

MARIA DYER. I am servant to Mr. Powell, of Lambeth. On 8th of Feb. the prisoner came for a pennyworth of milk, and gave me half-a-crown—I put it to my teeth; it went like a bit of sand—I sent it next door for change, which I gave the prisoner—the half-crown was afterwards brought back—I could tell it was the same by two marks I made by biting it—the prisoner came again for some more milk—I said, "You gave me a bad half-crown"—he said, "Did I?" and ran away—a man in the yard ran after him—he was caught, a policeman was fetched, and he was given in charge—I marked the half-crown again and gave it to the policeman—this is it—here are the two little dents I made with my teeth.

---- QUADIN. I followed the prisoner, caught him, and gave him in charge—I asked him for the change of the half-crown—he said he gave it to his brother—he wanted me to let him go to his brother's to get the change.
WILLIAM SMITH. I am the son of William Smith, a tripe-dresser. On 8th Feb. Dyer gave me a half-crown—I took it to Mrs. Croft—she gave me change.
MARY CROFT. William Smith came to me for change—I gave it him—I found the half-crown was bad after he was gone—I took it back to Mr. Powell's—I am sure it was the same.
WILLIAM HENRY MAINWARING (policeman, L 86.) It took the prisoner—I found a shilling in his right boot—I gave it to the inspector—I found no other money on him.
JOHN STEWARD ROGERS (police-inspector.) I saw this shilling found in the prisoner's boot—he said, "He gave it me"—I asked him who "he" was—he made no reply.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL. I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint—these are both counterfeit.

Prisoner's Defence. A man asked me to get him a pennyworth of milk, and gave me the half-crown; I got it, gave it him, and he went away; I met him again; he sent me for some more; the girl said it was a bad half-crows; I put the shilling in my boot and went for the man, but could not find him.

GUILTY. Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

963.
WILLIAM CLARK
, stealing 3 pairs of gloves, value 4s.; I necker
chief, 2s.; and 1 1/2 yard of holland, 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Joseph Skelton and another; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 25.—
Confined One Year.

964.
JAMES DELANEY
, stealing 7lbs. weight of pork, value 4s. 8d. the goods of
Abraham William Dupere, having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 35.—
Confined Six Months.

965.
CHARLES ATKINS
, stealing 2 waistcoats, 1 smock-frock, and 1 pair of gloves, value 1l., the goods of
Thomas Jury; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 28.—
Confined Three Months.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

966.
JOHN WILLIAMS and
JOHN SMITH
, stealing 4lbs. weights of pork, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
James Tarry; Williams having been before convicted; to which

WILLIAMS pleaded—
GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

SMITH pleaded—
GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Confined Two Months.

967.
WILLIAM DEFROND
, feloniously marrying
Mary Tanner, his former wife being alive; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 38.—
Confined Six Months.

968.
JOHN REVELL
, stealing 25lbs. weight of rope, value 2s., the goods of
William Chaplin and others; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Confined Three Days.
(The prisoner received a good character, and his master engaged to employ him.)

969.
WILLIAM PETTIT
, feloniously receiving 421lbs. weight of wool value 16l.; and two woollen bags, 4s.; the goods of
Thomas Dalby. (See page 683.)

THOMAS DALBY. I am a wool-dealer, in Marlborough-place, Kent-road—I have a warehouse in Grange-walk, Bermondsey—I saw a man named Verrall tried here last Session. On 24th Dec. I received information, went to my warehouse, and missed two bags of wool—I had not sold them.
Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. When was your warehouse closed? A. Generally about six o'clock—it was closed that night by a woman, who

is here—she had the keys—there was only one man there, who had the care of the horses—I have been to Mr. Broad's to make inquiries—I saw some wool there of the same kind as that I had lost, but I would not swear to it—it was finely combed wool—I know Mr. Broad to be a very respectable man.

WILLIAM DALBY. I am the nephew of Mr. Thomas Dalby. On 23rd Dec. I left his warehouse a little before six o'clock—I last saw the two bags of wool safe about four—I went next morning about nine o'clock, and the bags were gone—I saw an impression on some manure there, as if the bags had been on it—they would not have occasion to be put on it in the ordinary course of business.
ELIEA M'DONALD. I left the premises safe on Thursday night, 23rd Dec., next morning I found them all locked, as I had left them.

WILLIAM DALBY
re-examined. Q. Can you state how a person could get in? A. Over the gates outside, and by opening a trap-door—supporting that to be done, the manure was in such a position that the wool would be thrown upon it, and there were some locks of wool on the manure—a person might have got in at the scutch-door without breaking at all.

WILLIAM SWAN. I live with my father, a butcher, in Grange-road. Between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, on 23rd Dec., I was passing from Grange-road into Grange-walk—I saw Carney's horse and cart standing under Mr. Dalby's scutch-loft door—I knew Carney before—he was in the cart—directly the cart was backed up, the door was opened, and one bag was thrown down—it nearly went on Carney, and before he moved that one the other was sent down—I saw some persons in the loft, but I could not see who they were—I should say there must have been more than one, as the bags were thrown out so quick—Carney set the bags to rights and went away—I went and told my father.

THOMAS CARNEY. I am the brother of the man who was tried here last Sessions. On the Wednesday before Christmas, Verrall came to my mother's house—I did not know him, only by seeing him about the street—I did not know his name before—he used often to come to my mother's house for the horse and cart—I knew he was in Mr. Pettit's employ—mu brother was out at the time, delivering coke, and Verrall said he would call up again when he was ready—he said he wanted my brother to move some hurdles and things—he said his master sent him up for the cart—I told him I would send my brother down—Verrall went aways, and I did not see him again.

JOHN BARRETT. I am a coal-whipper—I am brother-in-law of Carney, who was tried here last Sessions. On the night of the 23rd Dec. I was at Carney's house, when Verrall came—I heard him say his master had sent him up for Carney to do a job for him—Carney said he would go, as he was ready—he went about seven o'clock, with his horse and cart—that place is about a quarter of a mile from where the wool was taken—next morning I was riding with Carney, and he got out and went into a yard in Russell-street—I saw the prisoner come down from the yard—he took Carney into a public-house, and paid him some money, and stood a pot of beer while he was paying him.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you even seen the prisoner before? A. No—this was on the Thursday before Christmas, about twelve or one o'clock in the day, at the Rose public-house—I was in the cart, and they called me to have a glass of beer—a young woman served us—I think I should know her if I saw her.
GEORGE MILLS EDWARDS. I live at Woolwich. On the 23rd Dec. I

lived as servant at Mr. Pool's, the Rose, in Russell-street, Bermondsey, Between seven and eight on that evening I saw Thomas Carney, with his cart, go up the turning alongside the Rose public-house, and draw up to Mr. Pettit's gateway, and I saw no more of him—I saw Verrall at the bottom of the yard—I had been in the yard about three minutes before—there were two bags of wool in the cart—next morning I saw the prisoner standing against his own gate, and there was a cart with a bag of wool in it, similar to what I had seen in Carney's cart the night before—I went to Mr. Wood's about my business, and when I came back the cart was gone—I saw the pri
soner again that day, in front of the Rose public-house, with Carney and his brother-in law—they had a pot of beer, and I saw some money pass from the prisoner, but I cannot tell what.

Cross-examined. Q. You were examined before, and the Jury disbelieved you? A. "I do not know, they acquitted the two prisoners—I am not doing anything now—I left Mr. Pool's in Jan.—I left on my own account, without giving notice—I went away in the evening, and did not go back—I went after my character—I lived with Mr. Pool from July last, and I lived before that with Mr. Buckeridge, a publican, for six months—I was not brought up to any profession—I have been to sea—I was never engaged in any smug
gling transaction—I lad off Deal for a week—I was assistant-steward of a convict ship for two years—I did not run any goods at Deal—I and my uncle have not been engaged in smuggling—before I was lying off Deal, I had been lying at Deptford and Woolwich, taking in prisoners—I now have my victuals and my lodging at my mother's—I walk about in the day, look
ing after a situation—I have heard of a situation this morning, to as servant in an engineer's office—I have done nothing since Jan, last—I live with my mother, and have not been out of Woolwich further than to Plum
stead and London, backwards and forwards—when I come to London, my mother pays my passage—I have no other means of getthing money, without I earn it—mu mother is a laundress—my father is living in Woolwich—he is a baker my trade, but he is bedrideen.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You lived in one situation two years, in another eighteen months, and in the last from July? A. Yes; and before I went to sea I lived with Mr. Dell, a wine-merchant, four years—I have a written character from my last place (producing it)—it was given me by Mr. Pool.

GEORGE RADFORD
police-sergeant, M 19.) I apprehended Carney, and began to look after the prisoner on 24th Dec., between nine and ten at night—I knew where he lived, but had not known him before—I was not able to find him at his premises—I made all the inquiries I could on the subject—I was not able to get him—I did not know Verrall before he was taken.

Cross-examined. Q. In the yard where the prisoner's premises are, are there not many people? A. There are workshops and warehouses—the pri
soner put in bail last Saturday fortnight—I have been looking for him before.

MR. BROAD examined by MR. PARRY. I know the prisoner—he is a fell
monger—I have purchased wool of him regularly two or three times a week—on 24th Dec. I purchased of him about a hundred weight super-head wool and about a hundred weight of Dutch—that was not the wool that Mr. Dalby looked at at my premises—he looked at some wool that came in three or four days afterwards from Mr. Pettit—what Mr. Dalby wanted to look at was combing wool—the other wool is short.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long have you dealt with the prisoner? A. I should say three or four months—I suppose when Mr. Dalby came, he came

for the purpose of seeing woll which had been stolen by Verrall and Carney, and had been sold to me by the prisoner—I was not there when he came—I heard he had come about some wool that the prisoner was supposed to have stolen—I know what wool Mr. Dalby saw, because I came in just as he went out—he saw the wool which the prisoner had delivered to me—it was lying out—it was called fine-combed wool—he said he could not swear to it—there was about 3 1/4 cwts. of it—I was not at home when it was brought, but I believe it was brought by Verrall and by Pettit's brother-in-law, on our track—I looked at it, and put a price upon it—I think I looked at it the day after it came, it was after Christmas—I believe it came in on a Monday—I did not look at it till Thursday or Friday—our foreman pointed it out to me—I know by the book when the wool came in—our foreman keeps the book—he is not here.

970.
EDWARD INGRAM
, stealing 2 sovereigns; the moneys of
Edward Willis.

EDWARD WILLIS. I live at Clapham. The prisoner lived with his grand
mother, and often came to my house—about a fortnight ago I missed the key of a box, in which I had four sovereigns—on 17th Feb. I opened the box, and there were but two soverigns in it.
ALEXANDER RAPLEY. I left the prisoner in the room where the sovereigns were, alone.

CHARLES BILLETT. I met the prisoner on Clapham-common—he pulled a key out of his pocket, and said that was the key that would get two or three couters out of Mr. Willis's box, and he meant to buy Hallet's little van, and a donkey, and set up a duster.
Prisoner. I said it was a key I picked up.
GEORGE CUTTINGS. I saw the prisoner in Brunswick-buildings, Clapham—he showed me two shillings—he, I, and some more boys, went to the play—next morning I saw him with two shillings more.
MAURICE SHANNON. The prisoners went with me to buy some boots—I saw him with three or four half-crosns.
HANNAH RULE. I sold the prisoner some bread—he gave me a half-sovereign.

FREDERICK LANGTON (police-sergeant, N 19.) I took the prisoner—I asked him what he had done with the key of the box—he said he had lost it—I asked how he came by it—he said he had found it by the old man's door.
prisoner. I did not have the money; I picked up a half-sovereign.

GUILTY . Aged 15.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.—
Confined Ten Days.

971.
JOHN CHESHIRE and
JOHN SLAUGHTER
, stealing 28lbs. weight of lead, value 3s.; the goods of
William Chaplin and others.

GEORGE WILLIAMS (policeman, V 94.) On 17th Feb. I was in Nine Elms-lane, at a quarter past six o'clock in the evening—I saw the prisoners together—Cheshire was carrying this basket—I stopped him, and asked what he had in it—he said, "Old lead," that it came from the Iron Steam-boat Factor, and they had been at work there—I asked them how they came by
it—Slaughter said they were allowed to take it—the basket contained 28lbs. of old lead.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Was not Slaughter a considerable distance from Cheshire? A. Not more than two yards—directly I stopped Cheshire, Slaughter came up, took a piece of lead out, and said, "We are allowed to take the old lead away."

GEORGE MARKS. I am foreman of the Iron Steam-boat Company's works, at Nine Elms. The prisoners were in the company's employ—they were repairing a barge, which had old lead in it—I saw it safe a day or two before—I received information that the prisoners had been taken about eight o'clock on the night of 17th Feb.—I examined the barge next morning, and missed the lead—it was similar to this—(produced) I believe this to be it.
COURT. Q. Are the men allowed to take the old lead? A. No—William Chaplin is one of the proprietors—there are others.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. How long had Cheshire been in the company's service? A. Four or five weeks—his wages were 5s. a day—I used to pay him—Slaughter was the senior hand, and in my absence he might give orders.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Do not the men have perquisites? A. No; they have choppings of wood—they do not take lead—I have been nine or ten years in the company's service, and Slaughter ten or eleven months—I do not know that any man could take 28lbs. of lead by mistake,

972.
JOHN CANE
, stealing 9lbs. weight of copper, value 6s.; the goods of
John Steavens and another, his masters.

JOHN STEVENS. I have one partner—we are engineers, at Southwark Bridge-road—the prisoner was in our employ occasionally—I missed a quan
tity of property from our premises from time to time, but not lately—this pipe, produced by the officer, is gas-fittings for devices for illuminations—it is drilled with holes—here is where the small pieces have been detached—it is ours—other persons make this article, but I can identify it as made on my premises.

THOMAS HAY (police-sergeant, M 9.) On 22nd Feb. I went into a marine-store dealer's shop in Montague-street, Southwark—I saw the prisoner and another man there—the other man made off—I saw a quantity of pipe in the scale—I asked the prisoner where he lived—he said in Spitalfields, and he brought the pipe from home—I said, "Could you not find a marine-store dealer's nearer than this?"—he said, "I was coming this way, whether or not"—I took him, and found in his pockets a quantity more pipe—I found on him his employer's card—I went there, and the pipe was identified.

Prisoner's Defence. I met a man, who said, "Come with me; I have some copper pipe to sell;" I went with him; the marine-store dealer would not buy it; the man said to me, "Put it in your pocket, and come along;" and just as we were coming out, the officer stopped us; plenty more makers make the same as this.
(The prisoner received a good character; and a witness engaged to employ him.)

GUILTY. Aged 26.—
Confined One Month.

973.
WILLIAM ARCHER
, stealing 1 till, and 7 shillings and 6 pence; the property of
william Urquhart; having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 14.—
Confined One Year and
Whipped.

974.
JAMES WRIGHT and
JAMES STEVENS
, stealing 28 cigars, value 3s.; the goods of
Henry Holdup; Wright having been before convicted; to which

WRIGHT pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 12.

STEVENS pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 15.

975.
ALEXANDER JAMES ROACH
, stealing 1 basket, value 1s.; 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 7 pence; the property of
Henry William Thompson, his master: 2nd COUNT, the property of
Ann Thompson, his mistress; having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 13.—
Confined Six Months and
Whipped.

976.
CHARLOTTE MALLOWS
, stealing 1 shift and 1 sheet, value 2s., the goods of
James Porter; and 1 sheet, value 1s., the goods of
Edward Mead: and
ANN WALKER
, feloniously receiving the same.

MARY ANN PORTER. I am the wife of James Porter, of 43, Lant-street, Borough. Mallows occupied the adjoining room to me in the same house—I had a shift and a shirt hanging to dry at the back of the house on 2nd Feb., about eleven o'clock—I missed them between twelve and one o'clock—these are them (produced).
Mallows. It is my own shift; you pawned if for me the week before.
Witness. I did not—it is mine.
Walker. Q. Have you any mark on it? A. I know it by the gussets and by the way it is made, by the narrow binder—the sheet has a tear in It—I told the policeman the mark before it was found.

EMMA BISHOP. I am the wife of John Bishop, of 29, William-street. The yard at the back of our house joins the yard of 43. Lant-street—Mallows lodges in that house—on Wednesday, 2nd Feb., at a little before twelve o'clock. I was in the yard—I saw Mallows take two sheets from a line in Porter's yard, go into the water-closet, fold them up, and then come and take the shift—I went into my own house, and soon after Mrs. Porter came and knocked at my door, and I told her what I had seen—we ran up to Mallows' door—she was not at home—she came home at half-past four o'clock, intoxi
cated, and said she was perfectly innocent—we told her if she would acknow
ledge it we would not give her in charge—she still denied it, and we gave her in charge.
EDWIN CHAPMAN. I am shopman to my father, a pawnbroker of Lock's-fields. I have a shift pawned on 2nd Feb. by Walker, and a sheet for 1s. 3d.
JAMES JOHNSON. I am in the service of Mr. Cattell, a pawnbroker of the Borough-road. I produce a sheet, pawned on 3rd Feb. by Walker—she gave her address, 4, Bond-street.

ROSETTA GIBBS. I live at 18, Salisbury-creacent; Walker is my landlady. On Wednesday, 2nd Feb., Mallows came, and them Walker asked me to hang a sheet and a shift by my fire—I allowed her to do so, thinking it was her own—I afterwards had to go to her room, and saw another sheet drying by her fire—she had been washing the day before—the prisoner was not then in her room.

FREDERICK LITCHFIELD (policeman, M 50.) I took Mallows—I told her it was on suspicion of having stolen two sheets and a shift—she said she was innocent, she knew nothing about them—I took Walker—I said it was on suspicion of receiving them, knowing them to be stolen—she said she was innocent.

MARY ANN MEAD. I am the wife of Edward Mead, of 43, Lant-street, where Porter lives. I hung out a sheet to dry, on 2nd Feb, on the same line with Mrs. Porter's—I missed it about one o'clock—this is it, produced by Mr. Chapman.

Walker's Defence. On 2nd Feb. Mallows came to my house and asked if I would take a sheet and shift to pawn; she said they were hers; I pawned them for 1s. 3d.; she gave me the ticket to mind till Saturday. On 3rd Feb. I went to her place, and heard she was taken for taking two sheets and a shift, I found it was true; I took my sheet and shift and pawned them for 9d. at Mr. Cattell's in the Borough-road; I took Mallows something to eat; I went into a public-house and saw Mr. Smith; he asked me if If had pawned anything, I said, "Yes, a sheet and shift for Mrs. Malllows, and a sheet and quilt of my own."

MALLOWS—
GUILTY. Aged 48.—
Confined Six Months.

WALKER—
NOT GUILTY.

977.
JOHN HENRY ALLEN and
RICHARD FOREMAN
, stealing 1 1/4 yards of oil-cloth, value 3s.; the goods of
Mary Ann Southgate.

ALLEN pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 14.—(see page 872.)

FOREMAN pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 13.—
Confined One Month.

978.
CHARLES BOOREE
, stealing 2 half-crowns, and 2 shillings; the moneys of
Thomas Lambert, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 33.—
Confined Nine Months.

979.
WILLIAM LAWLER
, stealing 1 sovereign; the moneys of
Mat
thew Hearder; having been before convicted.

MATTHEW HEARDER. I live in Skinner-street, Snow-hill, and am a boot and shoemaker. On 22nd Feb. I went in a cab to the Coal-hole—the driver got off, and we went in and called for ginger-beer—the prisoner was standing at the bar—I put down a sovereign to pay for the ginger-beer and a glass of rum—the prisoner snatched it and ran away with it—I am quite sure he is the man.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. This was at two o'clock in the morn
ing?A. Yes; I had been out, and stopped at the Surrey Coal-hole—the door was not opened and shut after each customer, at that time in the morn
ing—the door was open or I should not have gone in—I was not particularly cloudy from the drink I had taken—I did not hear any person say that the prisoner was not the man, when he was brought back.
WILLIAM HARBUD. I drove the cab—I went into the public-house—I drank my rum, and saw the prosecutor put a sovereign on the counter—I saw the prisoner take it up.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you been drinking? A. I had been taking a drop—it was between two and three in the morning—the prosecutor had been drinking, but was not the worse for liquor—he engaged me about two o'clock—I followed the prisoner—the door was pushed half-way to—I pulled it open and ran out—I called, "Stop thief! bring him back"—the police
man was in the act of bringing him back—I heard some persons say that he was not the person—I did not say, "I don't think he is, but I shall not have my fare if I don't say he is"—when I saw the sovereign taken I went out

immediately—the prisoner ran across the road—if course I could not run so fast as he did, I had my box coat on—there was a person in charge of the door—I said, "Shut the door, don't let him take my gentleman's money," and he shut it against me.

GEORGE BATSFORD (policeman, M 70.) I saw the cab-man draw up to the Surrey Coal-hole—in about five minutes the prisoner ran out of the door, and ran across the road and joined three persons—I caught hold of him and brought him back.

Cross-examined. Q. Is there not a watering-place by the side of the house? A. Yes—I could not mistake a person coming from there, or coming from the door—there is twenty yards between them—I was standing near the pit-entrance—I am quite sure I cannot be mistaken in the man that came out of the house.

THOMAS SMITH (City policeman, 270.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted Aug., 1846, by the name of William Spring, confined one year)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY. Aged 24—
Transported for Seven Years.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, APRIL 3RD, 1848.
